seg.output:
Dear brother, may you receive grace and peace from the Lord. There is a great reputation about the agreement and unity of your citizens towards the gospel, but there is also a rumor that a new war against the Quinquepagicos is about to break out soon. I do not wish for this to happen in these fragile and weak times. We have already seen how fighting against the enemy of God has not ended well. Why should we try to provoke Mars with such peril, which is so unlike Christian gentleness? I hope, however, that this rumor has no truth in it, since you are so devoted to the cause of peace.
I hear nothing of an agreement between you and the Bernatibus, which would be most beneficial. Please let me know through this good man what the state of public affairs is, especially those related to religion, and encourage and spur people to consider the altars and fire, so that they may eventually abandon their stubbornness. The unfortunate war has already ended unfortunately. Everyone is blaming each other for the damage we have brought upon ourselves. What can we do together to correct the errors we have committed? Many things have been hidden and it is not useful to bring them to light with mutual reproaches.

seg.output: I have heard nothing of an agreement between you and the Bernates, which could not be more advantageous. I beg you to indicate through this good man how public matters, especially those concerning religion, should be conducted, and meanwhile urge and encourage everyone to consider the altars and the hearth, as they say, so that they might finally abandon their stubbornness. This unfortunate war has been disastrously brought to an end. One blames another for the cause, and yet we have all suffered this disaster through our own admissions. What may we not now meditate on in repentance to correct what we have jointly committed? Many things have remained hidden, and it is not expedient for them to be brought to light through mutual revilements. I am glad that I have seen your Church, which I have considered closely and seen more clearly. But what need have I to ask concerning learning? And why should I doubt concerning piety, since it will become more firmly rooted day by day? This will be done through your ministry, my brother. You bear a great weight, namely the salvation of the Christian Republic over such a vast domain.

I would like to know if the senators have remitted the necessity of fighting for the parishioners. What has an apostle-like man in common with arms? It should be noted which feelings the ministry of the spirit imbues in the passion for fighting, then how it depresses the common people, and finally, that widows and orphans require a consoler at home, and therefore there are more souls that have been left behind at home than those that have rushed forth into the sudden turmoil of war. The pastor has taken on the care of these. I omit that there is little place for a tranquil spirit amongst arms, but an open field to exhort those who, out of fear, have stayed at home. By the arts of peace we, the ministers of the spirit, grow, not with unusual stratagems, which the very worst of men excel in. August 5th, 1532
Your Capito,
Heinrich Bulinger, Tigurine cleric and friend and brother.

seg.output: May peace and grace be from the Lord, dearest brother. There is a famous report of the great harmony and agreement among your citizens in the gospel, but there is a whispered rumor of a new war against the Quinquepagico, which may break out soon and near. I would not like this to occur at this time, when things are so delicate and weak. We have already seen battles fought against God's enemy. Why should we strive to provoke Mars again, so uncertain, so dangerous and so far from Christian gentleness? I hope that this rumor is false, since you pursue the studies of peace with such enthusiasm. Furthermore, I hear nothing of an agreement between you and the Bernatians, which could be nothing more beneficial. Please inform me through this good man how public affairs, especially those concerning religion, are conducted, and urge and encourage everyone to consider the altars and sacred fire, so they can finally abandon their stubbornness. This unfortunate war has ended miserably. Everyone is blaming someone else, but we all share in the blame for this disaster. What can we do together to correct the mistakes we have made? Many secrets remain hidden and it is not wise to expose them with mutual criticism.

seg.output: Furthermore, I would like to know if the senators have relieved the parishioners of the necessity of fighting. What, after all, does an apostolic man have in common with arms? It should be noted with what emotions the spirit of fighting instills the ministry, then how it depresses the crowd, and finally that widows and orphans need a comforter at home, and thus there are more souls left at home than those who have rushed into the sudden turmoil of war. The parish priest has taken on the care of these. Moreover, I hear nothing of an agreement between you and the Bernates, which could not be more conducive. I ask you, through this good man, to signify how public matters, especially those relating to religion, should be managed, and meanwhile to urge and stimulate everyone to consider altars and fire, as they say, so that they may finally depart from stubbornness of mind. This fatal war has been most unfortunately laid to rest. One blames the cause on another, yet we have all, with our admissions, deserved this disaster. What do we not meditate on repairing with penitence, that we have committed in common? For many things have been hidden, and it does not behoove them to be brought to light by mutual insults. I am glad that I have seen and considered your church more closely. For what shall I require as regards learning? And why should I doubt the piety, which is not deepening its roots more and more every day? Which will be done by your ministry, my brother. You bear the greatest burden, namely the safety of so great a dominion of the Christian republic. For you would moderate the religion of the private with less danger. Here it is necessary that you should take care that the magistrates neither do too much, nor nothing, in those things which are of the kingdom of Christ.

seg.output:
I wish to know if the senators have relieved the necessity of going to war for the parishioners. For what common thing is there between a man of the cloth and arms? It should be observed with what affections the spirit's ministry instills the desire of war, then, how it depresses the common people, and finally, that there is need of a comforter in the home for widows and orphans, and thus there are more souls left at home than those who have rushed out into the sudden tumult of war. The parishioner has taken this care upon himself. I omit how there is little place for a peaceful spirit among arms, but an open field for encouraging repentance among those who have stayed at home out of fear. We, ministers of the spirit, grow by the arts of peace, not by unusual strategies which the worst of men excel in. I wish to know if the senators have relieved the necessity of going to war for the parisioners.
Greet all your friends, not as if I were to enumerate their names; for I would rather be found grateful by deeds than words.
August 5th, 1532
Your Capito
To Heinrich Bulinger, a Tigurine ecclesiast and his friend and brother. Zurich.
